Title: Designing a Mission-Aligned Seminar
Narrative: You are preparing an upper-level interdisciplinary seminar at Soka University of America, but you're facing a challenge. Since you last taught it, students' study habits have changed. Now they are accustomed to using ChatGPT and other generative AI tools. You know most use it for brainstorming and finding sources, but the international students rely on it heavily for translation. Additionally, you suspect some students use it for writing and have been able to avoid AI detection tools by using "humanizers" and other methods designed to evade detection. As you outline the syllabus, you consider how each possible stance on AI could cultivate SUA's values, including leadership in humanism, intercultural dialogue, and pacifism. As you always ask when designing a course: How can you instill the excitement of your advanced topic and encourage students to use its knowledge to live virtuous and contributive lives? You consider five positions: 1) ignoring the issue and deferring decisions; 2) prohibiting AI outright; 3) allowing limited, ethical AI use; 4) permitting AI to support much of the work; and 5) designing the course to collaborate with students using AI tools. Each, you realize, involves risks and rewards. What will you choose?
Resource 1 Label: Soka University Mission
Resource 1 Why: Ground course goals in SUA's mission.

Title: The Decision to Maintain Status Quo
Narrative: You're facing a heavy workload this semester—committee work, research deadlines, and advising demands pile up. As you draft your syllabus, you decide to maintain the status quo, adding only a vague academic honesty statement: "Students are expected to submit their own work." This saves you dozens of hours of course redesign. You tell yourself you'll address AI properly next year, when you have more time. For now, you focus on the content you're passionate about teaching.
Resource 1 Label: EDUCAUSE Review (2024) — Faculty Workload
Resource 1 Why: Challenge of faculty time and effort in responding to AI.
Resource 2 Label: Medium (2024) — The Cost of Inaction
Resource 2 Why: Systemic risk of neglecting AI and avoiding difficult conversations.

Title: Cheating and Complacency
Narrative: Midway through the semester, you notice something troubling. Student papers suddenly show uniform polish—similar phrasing, consistent formatting, and a surprising lack of the usual errors. During office hours, two dedicated students confide their frustration: "Everyone else is using AI and getting away with it. We're working so hard, and they just paste prompts." You feel caught—you don't have time to investigate every assignment, but the inequity is obvious. Trust begins to erode, and you wonder if your silence communicated approval.
Resource 1 Label: EDUCAUSE Review (2025) — Erosion of Trust
Resource 1 Why: How lack of clear policy erodes student-faculty trust.
Resource 2 Label: HEPI (2025) — Student AI Survey
Resource 2 Why: Statistics on high student AI use and belief institutions aren't catching it.
Choice 1 Label: Acknowledge the integrity failure (switch to Prohibitive)
Choice 2 Label: Shift to literacy focus (switch to Balanced)

Title: Setting the Boundary
Narrative: You draft your new course policy: "AI-generated text is not permitted on any assignments." You frame it as protecting academic honesty and human dignity. You also point to SUA's commitment to be philosophers of a renaissance of life, pointing out that allowing machines to think for us or do our work appears to be the opposite of this motto. Finally, you point out that many important leaders have begun to sound the alarm on the potential destructive power of AI, and if your job is to help train the "pioneers of a global civilization," then humanity should be resisting AI, not embracing it, for it is already becoming weaponized. Students nod, although many seem unconvinced. One international student reluctantly and privately asks if translation tools count, while another asks if they can use Grammarly or Microsoft Word's "algorithmic grammar correction" tools.
Resource 1 Label: Frontiers in Psychology (2024) — From Tools to Threats
Resource 1 Why: Impact of AI chatbots on cognitive health and reliance concerns.
Resource 2 Label: PeerJ Computer Science (2025) — AI Detection Accuracy-Bias Trade-offs
Resource 2 Why: Empirical study showing AI detectors disproportionately affect non-native English speakers.

Title: The Translation Question
Narrative: A multilingual student confides: "I only use AI to translate readings so I can understand class discussion." You reaffirm your rule: each student should rely on their own effort to develop language skills. You remind yourself the policy safeguards fairness, yet you wonder if students continue to use AI. You take more time to check the AI detection tools, and two assignments raise concerns, but their probability scores are too low to confront the students. Participation drops, and you sense growing distance. At the same time, one student tells you during office hours that she appreciates your stance because she has resisted using AI, and feels that when her classmates use it, they are not learning and gain an unfair advantage.
Resource 1 Label: EAIE (2025) — AI and Language Learning
Resource 1 Why: AI promoting accessibility and inclusivity for international students facing language barriers.
Resource 2 Label: Center for Engaged Learning (2024) — AI Translation Tools
Resource 2 Why: Risk of losing cultural context and intercultural understanding with AI translation.
Resource 3 Why: Global equity standards for multilingual learning.

Title: The Enforcement Semester
Narrative: You implement AI detection software and restate strict consequences. Midterm, a false flag occurs — a student accused of AI use insists on innocence. The process consumes hours of investigation alongside meetings with the Dean of Students about due-process and dignity. Students stop visiting office hours; compliance rises, curiosity drops.
Resource 1 Label: Policy Brief (2025) — Rethinking AI Detection Tools
Resource 1 Why: Limitations and ethical risks of detection tools, emphasizing false positives and erosion of trust.
Resource 2 Label: Duke LILE — Authentic Assessment Over Surveillance
Resource 2 Why: Shifting from surveillance to authentic assessment.
Resource 3 Label: TEQSA — Evolving Risk to Academic Integrity
Resource 3 Why: Technical and legal analysis of detection tool flaws.

Title: Outcome: Integrity Preserved, Dialogue Lost?
Narrative: By the end of your course, your records show near-perfect compliance. But course evaluations describe your class as "serious, but tense" and one student remarks "I had trouble dismantling all the tools, like the automatic grammar checker and I don't think all of my classmates turned theirs off." You reflect: was integrity upheld, or did you and your students play "cat and mouse" all semester, distracting from the excitement you have previously shared in your field? Have your choices supported SUA's vision of graduates leading ethical lives?
Resource 1 Label: EdTech Magazine (2024) — Top IT Issues: Restoring Trust
Resource 1 Why: Strategies for repairing student-faculty relationships through trust.
Resource 2 Label: Max Planck Institute (2025) — AI Increases Dishonesty
Resource 2 Why: Empirical evidence on AI delegation and dishonest behavior.

Title: Designing the New Course
Narrative: You're drafting a syllabus for a new upper-level interdisciplinary seminar at Soka University of America. You know that students already use AI for translation, brainstorming, and writing support. Rather than ban it, you design a short unit on "Responsible AI Use" that ties directly to SUA's value of fostering leaders of humanism who can engage difference with empathy. Students will practice writing with and without AI, comparing their processes and reflecting on what they learn.
Resource 1 Label: EDUCAUSE (2024) — A Framework for AI Literacy
Resource 1 Why: Comprehensive framework for AI literacy in teaching and learning.
Resource 2 Label: UNESCO (2023) — Guidance for GenAI in Education
Resource 2 Why: Global ethical principles for human-centered AI integration.

Title: Ethical AI Workshops
Narrative: Week three. Students bring examples of AI output alongside their own writing. They identify what AI captures — and what it misses. Discussion turns lively: "How do we know when AI's help becomes substitution?" You surface SUA's mission and values, asking which uses cultivate leaders of culture in the community. You realize they're not just learning writing — they're learning judgment.
Resource 1 Label: EDUCAUSE (2024) — A Framework for AI Literacy (Executive Summary)
Resource 1 Why: Practical student and faculty competencies for ethical AI use.
Resource 2 Label: UNESCO (2023) — Guidance for GenAI in Education
Resource 2 Why: Global ethical principles for AI in education.

Title: Refining the Policy
Narrative: Together, the class revises its "AI Use Agreement." Students agree to cite AI assistance, reflect on their process, and take responsibility for final ideas. You highlight alignment with SUA's aim to foster leaders of culture who act with integrity. You notice improved confidence in emerging writers and fewer integrity concerns. Still, updating and clarifying the policy each semester takes time. Some colleagues worry: "Won't this gray area confuse students?"
Resource 1 Label: Campbell University — AI in Higher Education Survey
Resource 1 Why: Need for transparent policies and self-regulation.
Resource 2 Label: ResearchGate — Students' Acceptance and Self-Regulation of GenAI
Resource 2 Why: Self-regulation skills and GenAI acceptance.

Title: Outcome: Ethical Clarity Through Dialogue
Narrative: By term's end, students submit reflective essays describing how AI shaped their thinking. Most express gratitude for being trusted to decide responsibly. A few still wish for simpler rules, but many highlight new awareness: "I learned not just what AI can do — but what I can do with it." You guide them to name which SUA values their choices advanced: humanism, culture, pacifism, or contributive lives. You sense the course has fostered something deeper than compliance: wisdom linked to mission.
Resource 1 Label: Wageningen University — In AI We Trust?
Resource 1 Why: Human judgment and wisdom must lead, not mere reliance on technology.

Title: Rethinking the Assignment
Narrative: You sit at your desk drafting the syllabus for your new upper-level interdisciplinary course. You know students already use AI for brainstorming and translation. Instead of policing that reality, you wonder: "What if I invited AI use as part of the process itself?" You rewrite a major paper assignment into an "AI-Reflection Portfolio," where students must document prompts, evaluate AI output, and annotate what they learned about thinking itself. You frame the experiment as cultivating leaders of pacifism who can resolve complex problems with creativity and care.
Resource 1 Label: TEQSA (2025) — Assessment Redesign
Resource 1 Why: Models for institutional assessment redesign focusing on integrity and authenticity.
Resource 2 Label: EDUCAUSE Review (2025) — The AI Tsunami
Resource 2 Why: Shift to human-centered approach fostering collaboration and creativity with AI.

Title: First Iteration
Narrative: Students experiment with AI during early drafts. Some produce nuanced reflections; others hand in work too dependent on the tool. In discussion, you model critical use: showing how to question AI's assumptions. The room fills with excited and uncertain energy. One student says, "I've never thought so much about how I write." Another links the work to preparing for peacebuilding dialogues abroad.
Resource 1 Label: Transparent AI Integration — Best Practices for Citing AI
Resource 1 Why: Guide for transparent AI use and critical engagement.
Resource 2 Label: Education Development Trust — Metacognition
Resource 2 Why: Teaching metacognitive strategies for deeper learning.

Title: The Assessment Challenge
Narrative: Grading portfolios takes longer than expected. You realize authentic work requires new evaluation criteria, and growth, insight, and self-reflection now matter more than grammar or format. A peer asks, "Isn't this subjective?" You reply, "Maybe, but so is learning." By mid-semester, students begin referencing AI critically in discussions about ethics, bias, and creativity, connecting the seminar to Soka's vision of graduates leading contributive lives.
Resource 1 Label: OECD — AI and Education and Skills
Resource 1 Why: Policy analysis on how AI shifts skills demand and assessment priorities.
Resource 2 Label: EDUCAUSE Review (2025) — Beyond Tool or Threat
Resource 2 Why: Reimagining purpose and values in authentic assessment.
Choice 1 Label: Partner with the Pacific Basin Research Center

Title: Outcome: Innovation and Depth
Narrative: At semester's end, students present reflective projects titled "What I Learned From My AI Mistakes." Their work is messy, honest, and profound. Some still rely too much on the tool, but most articulate a clearer sense of authorship. You feel both exhausted and inspired. When you share at a Writing Center AI workshop, a colleague says, "This feels like the future of Soka education: humanistic, creative, responsible." Another confides later on that he doesn't have the time and hasn't gotten the training to repeat your experiment in his course.
Resource 1 Label: EDUCAUSE Review (2025) — A More Human University
Resource 1 Why: Scaling meaningful, individualized learning experiences with AI.
Resource 2 Label: EDUCAUSE Review (2025) — Ethics Is the Edge
Resource 2 Why: Ethical imperative for governance aligning AI with academic values.

Title: Opening the Dialogue
Narrative: You begin the semester with an open question: "How should we, as a learning community, engage with AI?" Instead of dictating rules, you invite students to share experiences — how AI has helped, hindered, or confused them. Together, the class drafts an "AI Reflection Charter" that commits to transparency, curiosity, and mutual respect, explicitly linking the work to SUA's mission of fostering leaders of pacifism and humanism.
Resource 1 Label: EDUCAUSE Review (2025) — In the Room Where It Happens
Resource 1 Why: Creating room for diverse perspectives in AI policy creation.
Resource 2 Label: UNESCO (2023) — Guidance for GenAI
Resource 2 Why: Human-centered vision for GenAI in education.

Title: Shared Experimentation
Narrative: Each week, students log one AI interaction — a prompt, a response, and their reflection on it. In class, small groups analyze where the tool enhanced or hindered their thinking. Surprisingly, students begin to critique AI's biases and limits more deeply than expected. You frame the practice as nurturing leaders of culture in the community who can steward technology with care.
Resource 1 Label: Campbell University — AI in Higher Education Survey
Resource 1 Why: Student-faculty collaboration on ethical AI guidelines.
Resource 2 Label: EDUCAUSE Review (2025) — A More Human University
Resource 2 Why: Scaling deep, individualized, metacognitive learning with AI.
Resource 3 Why: SIGS projects for global cooperation embodying collaborative spirit.

Title: AI in the Classroom Workshop
Narrative: Colleagues hear about your approach and invite you to a workshop on AI in writing and pedagogy. You share anonymized student reflections, both breakthroughs and confusions. Another professor worries about workload: "How do we grade process fairly?" You agree: collaboration requires new assessment norms. The group plans a small cross-course study grounded in SUA's values. You worry that this will require 10 hours of work, time you don't have, but it feels necessary.
Resource 1 Label: Harvard GSE — AI Can Add to Learning
Resource 1 Why: AI adding value to learning, ideal for faculty discussion.
Resource 2 Label: EDUCAUSE Review (2024) — Exploring Opportunities and Challenges
Resource 2 Why: Institutional imperative for stakeholder conversations on AI policy.
Choice 2 Label: Move toward formal policy (switch to Balanced)

Title: Outcome: Dialogue Becomes the Curriculum, But is it Sustainable?
Narrative: By semester's end, your class talks about AI as easily as about literature or ethics. Students report feeling trusted, and more responsible as a result. Faculty peers adapt your reflective logging model. The project closes with a sense of optimism, not that you've solved AI in education, but that you've learned to face it together. Still, you know not every course or instructor has the time for this level of mentoring and you worry that the technology is changing much faster than professors and the university can adapt.
Resource 1 Label: EDUCAUSE Review (2025) — Ethics Is the Edge
Resource 1 Why: Pragmatic ethical framework for integrating AI through dialogue.
Resource 2 Label: OECD — AI and Education and Skills
Resource 2 Why: Analysis of AI impact on learning and skills, linking collaboration to equity.

Title: Teaching for Value Creation in the AI Era
Narrative: As you moved through the pathways, you balanced integrity, creativity, equity, and trust under real constraints. Summarize what you protected, what you risked, and what you learned. Then, connect those insights to SUA's mission of humanistic, contributive education. What is one concrete next step you will take to integrate these lessons into your next seminar's design, assessment, or dialogue? Thank you for participating in Soka AI Pathways Explorer!
Resource 1 Label: SUA Mission and Values
Resource 1 Why: Anchor reflections in founding principles.

Title: Human Rights Case Workshop
Narrative: You anchor the seminar in a human-rights case study drawn from the Pacific Basin. Teams map how AI could support research, storytelling, or advocacy, documenting risks to dignity and accuracy. Students connect decisions to SUA's founding principle of upholding human rights. Debate runs hot when one team argues AI translation could amplify marginalized voices faster.
Resource 1 Label: Pacific Basin Research Center
Resource 1 Why: PBRC's mission for humanistic development and human rights in Asia-Pacific.
Resource 2 Label: UNESCO (2023) — Guidance for GenAI in Education
Resource 2 Why: Ethical guardrails for justice-focused work.

Title: Community Partnership Dilemma
Narrative: A Student Fellow from the Pacific Basin Research Center asks if your seminar could help her co-create narratives for a justice campaign. Students debate whether to use AI for rapid translation and story drafts. Some argue it could amplify marginalized voices; others worry about accuracy and consent. You remind them of the need to balance efficiency with respect and accuracy.
Resource 1 Label: Pacific Basin Research Center
Resource 1 Why: PBRC's mission for peaceful, humanistic development of Asia-Pacific region.
Resource 2 Label: USIP — Peacebuilding Toolkits
Resource 2 Why: Framework for incorporating conflict management and peacebuilding concepts.
Resource 3 Why: Protecting cultural and linguistic diversity when using GenAI.

Title: Community Storytelling Lab
Narrative: Your seminar partners with the Writing Center to host a community storytelling lab. Student teams craft guidelines for using AI to support oral histories from local activists. They debate whether AI summaries honor or flatten lived experience, anchoring decisions in SUA's principle of educating leaders of culture in the community.
Resource 1 Label: Helping Writers Become Authors — Intentional Storytelling in the AI Era
Resource 1 Why: How AI risks losing an authentic voice in storytelling.
Resource 2 Label: The Guardian (2025) — AI as a Tool to Sharpen Storytelling
Resource 2 Why: AI can improve storytelling, but only if used well.
Resource 3 Why: Writing support for ethical narrative practices.
